content: The Act titled "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" requires states to have laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years of age. It is illegal for individuals under 18 years of age to purchase, receive, or possess tobacco products in public places. Law enforcement agencies must take action if a minor is found to have bought or received tobacco products. Persons under 18 are prohibited from purchasing or possessing tobacco products in public places. Law enforcement must notify parents if a minor is caught with tobacco products. Within 180 days of a State law taking effect, retail tobacco distributors must inform employees about the prohibition of selling tobacco products to individuals under 18 years old. Within 180 days of a State law taking effect, retail tobacco distributors must inform employees about the prohibition of selling tobacco products to individuals under 18 years old to ensure compliance with the law. Employers are not in violation if they rely on proof of age. Employers are not in violation of selling tobacco products to individuals under 18 if they rely on valid proof of age or implement a program. Violators may face civil penalties and community service. Some states have delayed applicability of these regulations. In certain states, the requirement for compliance with tobacco regulations may be delayed to fiscal year 2012 and beyond for states without regular legislative sessions in 2010 and 2011. The requirement for compliance with tobacco regulations for states receiving grants under section 1921 will apply from fiscal year 2012 onwards. States must establish goals to reduce retailer violations of the law, with a target violation rate of 20 percent during fiscal year 2010. The subsection mandates annual, random, unannounced inspections to limit violations to specific rates each fiscal year, starting at 20% in 2010 and decreasing annually to 12% in 2018. The law mandates decreasing violation rates annually from 16% in 2014 to 10% in 2020 and beyond, with enforcement required by states receiving grants under section 1921. Enforcement of the law described in subsection (a) is required for states receiving grants under section 1921 to reduce the availability of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years of age through random, unannounced inspections. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 requires the State to conduct annual random, unannounced inspections to ensure compliance with the law and submit a report to the Secretary detailing enforcement activities and success in the previous fiscal year. The State seeking a grant must demonstrate the success in meeting goals and reducing tobacco availability to minors, as well as outline strategies for enforcing the law in the upcoming fiscal year. The State seeking a grant must show success in reducing tobacco availability to minors and outline enforcement strategies for the upcoming fiscal year. A funding agreement allows the State to involve individuals under 18 in compliance testing with parental consent. The State can involve individuals under 18 in compliance testing with parental consent and direct supervision during random inspections. Funding agreements for grants require States to certify their expenditures in the previous calendar year. The State must certify that over 10% of the funds from the November 1998 settlement were spent on health programs, tobacco control, cessation activities, or economic development for tobacco regions to qualify for a grant under section 1921. Noncompliance will be determined by the Secretary before granting funds. Before granting funds under section 1921, the Secretary will determine if the State has complied with spending requirements on health programs, tobacco control, cessation activities, or economic development for tobacco regions. If noncompliance is found, the State's allotment may be reduced after a hearing. The Secretary may reduce the State's allotment under section 1921 if noncompliance with subsections (a), (b), or (c) is found after a hearing, by an amount equal to 10 percent of the amount determined under section 1933 for the State for the fiscal year. The State's allotment under section 1921 for the fiscal year may be reduced based on specific percentages determined under section 1933 for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2013. The State's allotment under section 1921 for the fiscal year may be reduced by specific percentages determined under section 1933 for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2013, with additional reductions if the State is not in compliance with certain subsections. Beginning with the first applicable fiscal year, if the Secretary determines that a State is not in compliance with certain subsections, the allotment under section 1921 may be reduced by 10 percent of the amount determined under section 1933 for that fiscal year. This reduction is in addition to any other reductions already in place. The Secretary will provide assistance in developing and implementing State laws, including model legislative language and technical guidance. The Secretary will assist states in developing and implementing laws by providing model legislative language and technical guidance. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is amended to make ingredient information accessible to the public online within 48 hours of submission to the Secretary.
